subject: Re: Test naming conventions (was Re: [junit] Unit Testing question)
msgSnippet: Ditto, but usually: testPushEmptyStack() testPushStackWithOneElement() testPushFullStack() testPushNullElement() ... From: jason r tibbetts
messageBody:
Ditto, but usually:
testPushEmptyStack()
testPushStackWithOneElement()
testPushFullStack()
testPushNullElement()

-------------- Original message --------------
From: jason r tibbetts <tibbettj@...>
Mark Levison wrote:
>>> What's a better approach - isolate each method and test accordingly,
>>>or test at the class level?
>>
>>Between those two, I generally test methods, but really, I test
>>/behaviors/, most of which I implement with a single method. In this
>>case, testing behaviors and testing methods is essentially the same.
>>
>>A classic example of when I need to test behavior instead of methods is
>>a Stack. You don't really test push(), but rather test peek() and pop()
>>using push(), and this is how we know push() works. One test, then,
>>might be check that after pushing into an empty stack, I can peek at the
>>top item. One could argue this tests push, or peek, or both. I don't
>>care which. What I generally care about is that push, peek and pop work
>>on an empty stack.
>
> +1 Then the trick becomes naming the test well.

On that note, what conventions does everyone here use to name their test
methods? For this example, mine would look like:

test_push_emptyStack()
test_push_stackWith1Element()
test_push_fullStack()
test_push_nullElement()

in other words,
"test" + /primary/ method under test + scenario description

I've also considered names that indicate whether an exception is
expected, such as

test_push_nullElement_throwsIAX() // IllegalArgumentException

but I've rejected this convention for aesthetic reasons.
